titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V. Thursday

Walk with E. Price Greenleaf on the Neponset Bridge road and round the Square by the Black-smith’s Corner— T. Adams jr. Tax-collector—paid him parish tax bill— My Assessments— Charles, and his wife with Louisa C. and the baby left us and went in to Boston— Another wasted day— Wrote Nothing

2 IV. Friday— Walk with Price Greenleaf to Penn’s Hill— Met there Lewis Bass, Selectman and Noah Curtis— Propositions to take of my land for the benefit of the Town— To see Mr Bass this Evening but missed him.— Day wasted but Mary wrote for me four short answers to letters— Evening call at Mrs T. B. Adams—and thence, Evening at Mr Edward Millers
3. IV. Saturday

Walk with E. Price Greenleaf to the Slate-quarries—two. L. C. Henninger, a native of Baden, brought me a manuscript against the Jesuits for advice— I declined— President Quincy paid a morning visit— My Letter of 7. Septr to D. J. Pearce is published in this morning’s daily Advocate with a mistake of the press. My wife and Mary went this afternoon to Weymouth. Transplanted seedling apple and pear trees from box one to rows in cleared hazel-bush patch—
4. V. Sunday— Communion day—

Heard Mr P. Whitney in the morning from 1. Corinthians 15.50. and Mr Lunt P.M. from Romans 5.4. The Communion was administered by both Pastors after the morning service— Afternoon Mr Lunt’s daughter was baptised Mary Elizabeth, and Burrell’s Son William Lucius The collection was taken up for the sufferers by the fire at Charlestown— Notice that henceforth during the Winter the second morning bell will ring at 1/2 past 10. and the afternoon Bell at 1/4 before 2— Read Saurin’s Sermon 13. vol 7. third on regeneration— Eliz. C Adams dined with us— E Price Greenleaf here this Evening— I walked to Coll. Quincy’s and spent the Evening there Returned her book the Journal of Mr Alcott’s School— Mary and her two children were at meeting morning and afternoon—
5. IV. Monday.

Walk with E. Price Greenleaf, round by Capen’s, the Lawyer’s Common, and Ebr. and Josiah Adams Lewis Bass came and agreed to take the corner lot on the brow of Penns Hill, for 200 dollars, he to accommodate the town, by cutting away the corner— Kept house the whole day—finished Letter to D. J. Pearce— Comments from Boston on my letter to him of 7. ulto. Letter from A. H. Everett—

6. IV:15. Tuesday— Walk with E. Price Greenleaf to the brow of Penn’s Hill— Measured the corner lot by pacing—18 paces front—30 deep 27 to the road— Shortened our walk—but were overtaken by a shower— Showery day—burnt Kitchen, Parlour and my chamber chimneys— Made draught of deed to Lewis Bass.— Letter from J. Forsyth— Time consumed in searching for papers—found 23 plans by L. Humphreys and M. Withington of my land’s— Baxter lot missing
7. IV. Wednesday

Call on E. Price Greenleaf walk round square by Arnold’s Brook, and back by Scotland pond— Met Newell Adams Shewed Lewis Bass, draft of deed which he approved Call on T. Greenleaf to ask him to take the acknowledgment of deed— His commission has expired, and he has not taken the Oath upon its renewal— J. A. Brown Thomsonian Agent came and asked me to return a book Thomsons’s new guide to health, and life, which he gave me two years ago— I promised to look it up and return it— Lewis Bass was here this Evening, but the Deed not being ready, will come again to-morrow— Mary spent the Evening at Mrs T. B. Adams’s
8. IV: Thursday—

Walk with E. P. Greenleaf to the Germantown wharf— Returning stopp’d at L. Brackett’s and asked him to come and take the acknowledgment of the deed to Lewis Bass, which he did— Charles came out from Boston: dined with us and returned at Night— Went with him and William Spear over the hill—met and treated with Colman to open the ledge— Charles, is to draw up the agreement— Elizabeth C. Adams dined and spent the day here— Mr Beale and his daughter were here late this Evening— Lewis Bass came, and I delivered the Deed to him.— Talk about Wheeler’s repairing the Meeting House.
9. IV. Friday

Walk with E. Price Greenleaf round the Neponset Bridge and Gulliver’s Brook Square— Morning visit from Mr Peter Whitney. Call from Thomas Vinson, who left with me a petition for increase of his pension— He is eighty years old— His Grandson has returned home from Holland, discharged from the king’s navy there— Letters from T. Burges and Bellamy Storer.— Afternoon in the Garden—planted row 11. in Cleared Hazelbush patch.
10. IV. Saturday

Walk with E. P. Greenleaf by Miller’s houses to the Weymouth turnpike— On my return I called at Dr Woodwards and he drew my tooth— Alpheus Spear came again about his lease, but we did not agree— Mr Joscelyn came to speak for Timber at Mount Wollaston— Comings called for his land warrant which I gave him— He said there was another. Charles with his wife and daughter Louisa C came and dined with us and returned this Evening— Alexander H. Everett and George Bancroft came out after dinner, and remained till Evening— Wrote to Bellamy Storer and T. Burges.
11. IV:15 Sunday.

Heard Mr Lunt this morning from Philippians 3.9 upon Faith— Admirable— Afternoon from Hebrews 4.15. Christ as an high Priest.— Mrs T. B. Adams and Louisa C. Smith dined with us. Messrs. M’Connell, Tileston and Allen of Carthage Smith County Tennessee were here while we were at Meeting this Morning— Wanted to see the House— I read Sermon 14. Vol. 7. of Saurin upon the presence of God— George Nightingale the Town Clerk gave me a Letter from Solomon Lincoln asking extracts from the Braintree Town Records relating to the mother of John Hancock—and asked me to answer it, which I did— In the Evening saw the Comet in Ursa Major— I told Mr Joscelyn I could not go to Mount Wollaston before next Wednesday afternoon. He agreed to meet me there then— Fire in Boston last Night.
12. IV. Monday

Walk with E. P. Greenleaf round by the Braintree Meeting-House and by the Cross road back by the Weymouth Turnpike— I saw the Comet this Morning and again this Evening— E. P. Greenleaf was again here this Evening. I answered a Letter from Russell Freeman Afternoon in my Garden Nursery and Seminary— Planted a whole Orange Pear with Apple—Pear and Ash seeds in box N. 1. and another cross row at the eastern end of the seminary.
13. IV. Tuesday

Precisely at 5. O’Clock this morning E. P. Greenleaf came and I walked with him to Boston—2. hours and 5 minutes to the free bridge. 2 hours and 20 minutes to my Son Charles’s house—N. 3. Hancock Avenue; we breakfasted there, and then Mr Greenleaf left me— I visited Mr Charles Codman and William Lee, both of whom I found at home. Dr Wainwright was out, but I afterwards met him in the Street. I called at the U.S. Branch Bank and took a credit for 500 dollars on a check upon the Branch Bank at Washington.— Called at Kelley and Hudson’s shop, and took a Cloak instead of the Great Coat
which I had purchased there and returned— At Dr. Abner Phelps’s, where I met Samuel D. Greene, one of the victims of Masonic Calumny, who gave me a pamphlet in vindication of his character— Mr Odiorne came in while I was there— I called twice on Dr Jacob Bigelow— Found him at home the second Time—and consulted him upon the state of my health and the condition of my Constitution— He sent me his opinion in a Letter this Evening. Dined at Charles’s, with Alexander H. Everett and B. F. Hallett. Charles in the Evening went with his wife to the Play— A. H. Everett went away about 8 in the Evening— Hallett remained until Charles came home from the Theatre.— Hallett told me that Edward Everett had assured him in a Letter, that as between Mr Van Buren and H. L. White, he should prefer Van-Buren for President of the United States— That D. Webster had given him verbally the same pledge; and that he Hallett had during the Rhode Island election of Senator of the United States had gone to Providence authorised by Webster to pledge this assurance to the Anti-Masons to prevail upon them to vote for Sprague for the Senate— Now the Whig Papers in Boston denounce as a heinous crime the preference of Van Buren to White, and Everett appeals to the generosity of Hallett not to expose him— There was a cry of fire, and a ringing of the bells as I was going to bed, which kept me awake till near Midnight.
14. VI. Wednesday—

I awoke this morning as usual before four O’Clock but was obliged to wait till daylight, to rise; and then amused the time till breakfast with a volume of Enfield’s Philosophy,—History— After breakfast, I called successively to see A. H Everett, and B. F. Hallett, but found neither of them at home— I called also at the Fremont House to see Mr George Bancroft but he was not there— I visited Dr George Parkman, and had an hour of conversation with him, upon Fanny Kemble Butler and her father, and sundry other subjects— He engaged me to dine with him next Wednesday— At home Charles came out with me to Quincy, dined with us, and returned after dinner to Boston— Mr Joscelyn came at 4. in the afternoon, and I went with him to the Mount-Wollaston Farm— There I met Captain John Souther
and his Son— They and Joscelyn wanted Oak-timber for ship-building— They pointed at several trees for which they offered various prices from 5 to 2 dollars— Joscelyn said he would make an offer for each tree standing, or for the timber by the ton delivered at his yard; or a round sum for the whole— They finally advised me to sell at Auction, in lots.— Joscelyn brought me back as far as Frenchs tavern, and thence I walked home.
15. IV. Thursday.

No morning walk— I answered a Letter from S. R. Hanscom—Secretary of the Moral Lyceum at Lowell inviting me to deliver a Lecture before them—which I declined— I wrote also to Mr Frye at Washington, and began an answer to two Letters from Dr Waterhouse— Visited my garden and Nursery which are desolate— Kirk is transplanting Elms, Oaks and Horse-Chesnuts—opened a row in the Orchard East of the Nursery— Josiah Adams junr. came down this afternoon and I went with him to the Mount Wollaston farm— He went all over the House with Alpheus Spear the Tenant, who explained to him the manner in which he wished the House to be taken down, and another built—and the addition to the barn near the House— Spear’s estimate is about 2500 dollars— Adams thinks it will amount to more— Both of them advise me to sell the Timber by the Ton— Walked home— E. P. Greenleaf was here this Evening—the Comet increases nightly in splendour moving southward and westward from the Great-Bear.—
16. IV. Friday

Mr Greenleaf came this morning by half past four— We walked upon the Braintree and Weymouth Turnpike, and returning stop’d at William Spears— I asked him to go with Mr Joscelyn to the Mount Wollaston forest To mark with him all the trees wanted by Joscelyn and receive his offers for them— He came afterwards with Joscelyn’s proposals— They had marked 204 trees for which he offered 591 dollars or 8 dollars a tree, delivered at his yard— I thought
it would be best to sell by the ton, and Spear engaged to take a Ship-carpenter from Braintree down to the forest to view the trees and estimate their value— My wife and Mary went to Boston, dined at Charles’s and returned after dinner— E. Price Greenleaf dined with me, and after dinner visited with me, my Garden and Nursery I finished my Letter to Dr Waterhouse, and this was the labour of the day— All the factions in the Country are pouring out their fury upon me, for my Letter to D. J. Pearce of 7. Septr. which they screwed him to publish— There never has been so universal a combination to ruin me in public estimation.
17. IV. Saturday.

Met Mr Greenleaf half way between my house and his father’s— We walked to the Rail-way Quarries, and visited the two lodges opened this year upon my lands— One of them is so unsuccessful that it must fail, and the other is already nearly exhausted— Charles with his wife and daughter came out and dined with us and returned at Night— Elizabeth C. Adams spent the afternoon and Evening here— Saw the Comet in bright splendor on the knee of Hercules, with a long trail of light ascending the sky—viewed it through the glass, and with the naked eye— I received a second Letter from T. Burges; and answered two from S. S. Southworth with the Bangor Courier of 13. October: a curious Article upon Burges—
18. IV. Sunday

Heard Mr Lunt this morning from 1. Corinthians 7.29. But this I say brethren, the time is short— An admirable; and to me most deeply affecting discourse— The allusions to the Comet, and to the centurial anniversary of my fathers birth, as illustrations of the brevity of any give portion of time were more than beautiful—the last truly pathetic— Mrs T. B. Adams, Elizabeth C, and
Louisa C. Smith dined with us— In the afternoon, Mr Huntoon of the Railway-Church preached form Isaiah 64.6. “We all do fade as a leaf.” It was a misfortune for Mr Huntoon who is an excellent preacher that his subject was nearly the same which Mr Lunt had treated this morning Mr Huntoon’s discourse was positively good—but comparatively inferior— I read the 15th. and last Sermon of the 7th. volume of Saurin—upon the delays of God to punish Sinners— I was unable to command application of mind to read profitably being involuntarily absorbed with other cares— Began to read Dissertation H—upon the Congress of Nations— My hand yet much disabled and my diary running in irretrievable arrears.
19. IV:15. Monday—

Walk this morning with E P. Greenleaf over Penn’s hill, returning by the Weymouth Turnpike— My hand is still crippled— I received a Letter from George Bancroft with the Morning Post, containing the address of the Democratic Convention of young men at Worcester upon nominating Martin van Buren for President of the United States, Richard M. Johnson for Vice-President— Marcus Morton for Governor of this Commonwealth and William Foster, for Lieutenant Governor— The Address was written by Bancroft himself a recent convert to Democracy; of which it gives new definitions and a very ingenious and plausible theory— I wrote at the request of Dr George Parkman the substance of my observations to Fanny Kemble, at his Table, to which she alludes in her Journal and misrepresents— After dinner, I planted in the cleared hazel bush patch in my garden a row of Pear-Cores (garden button and St. Michaels) with Apple-seeds—Acorns, Thornberry’s—Shagbark Nuts, from the young seedling Cherry-tree, and in the Seminary next the gate, two Cores of Brown-Bury Pears, with Greenleaf red Apple-seeds 5 wild plums, and several Ash seeds— Mr John P. De Wint and his daughter Caroline arrived this Evening— Mary went
with them to Mrs T. B. Adams’s, and returned about nine in the Evening—
20. IV. Tuesday.

With Mr De Wint, and his daughter Caroline, I came in the Stage to Boston— They were going this day to Lowell— We had invited, and urged Caroline to stay with us till we go on to Washington—but she declined— I called for five minutes, at Charles’s house, and thence walked to Cambridge, and attended the meeting of the Committee of the board of Overseers— There were present of the Committee the Lieutt. Governor S. T. Armstrong—Revd. Dr. Jenks,Richardson, and Sidney Willard— Mr Isaac C. Bates was also there— At 4. O’Clock there was an Exhibition— Upon the whole quite indifferent— I do not recollect having before been present at an exhibition since I had myself a part in one—April 1787.— An exhibition at that day, was in my estimation the most important of human events—next to Commencement day— How flat, stale and unprofitable now!— The best performance was a Poem, by Minns, in the Scottish measure of verse— The speaking was universally bad— Half the performances were translations from English into Latin and Greek.— The English Oration by West was very much below mediocrity— A report on the present State of the University was presented by President Quincy, with particular Reports from professors Ware father and H. and J. Ware Sons, Palfrey, E. T. Channing; Beck, Felton, Giles, Peirce— I arrived so late that I had not time to read these reports, but they were put into my hands by the Chairman of the Committee Govr Armstrong, and I took them with me— After the exhibition we had a temperate dinner— I visited Dr Waterhouse, and spent half an hour with him— Then returned with Governor Armstrong in his carriage; with Mr Bates and Mr Richardson— We alighted before the State house yard— Govr. Armstrong being engaged to attend a Meeting of the Council— I came to my Sons House— He and his wife went to an Evening party at Mr S. B. Barrells, and I retired to bed—
21. V. Wednesday.

I called twice this morning, once before, and once after breakfast at Governor Armstrong’s new house— The first time about 8 he was not up. The second time he received me—and I had two hours of conversation with him— I returned to him the Reports of President Quincy and of the Heads of Departments which I had received from him yesterday—and asked him what were the duties of the Committee— He did not exactly know— There would be a Report to be made to the Board of Overseers, at their meeting in January next; but it was a mere formality— He proposed to look up the Report of the last year, and to follow it as a precedent— I said I knew not precisely what the duties of the Committee were, but I presumed they were, to inspect the condition of the University and to report the same in writing to the Board of Overseers I had read this morning the Reports of President Quincy, and of the Heads of Departments,—and regretted that I had arrived yesterday so late, that I could not then read them— Upon perusing them this morning, the question had occurred to me whether they were complete— That is whether all the subordinate reports required by the usage were made— He said the Report from the Professor of Law, had not been made quite in time; but he expected to receive it to day— I asked why there was no Report from the Professor of Natural philosophy and Astronomy. He said he believed the Professor, Farrar, was not upon good terms with the corporation—but that was no reason, why he should not have made a Report— I asked why there was no report from the Librarian— He said that was made to another Committee. This introduced a general discussion upon the condition of the University, and the duties of the visiting Committee, in which I urged him to make a report, to the board of Overseers, not merely formal, but such as might call the attention of the board to any deficiencies or abuses in the management of the Institution itself— He promised to ascertain from the Secretary of the Board Dr Pearce, what are the precise duties of the
Committee, to consult with the other members of the Committee, (only 5 of whom, out of ten attended the Meeting) and to prepare a Report, which he would submit to my consideration, before the meeting of the Board in January—I have sown this conversation of with Governor Armstrong as seed— I believe the University needs an electric shock to restore it from a paralytic state, and I will make an effort to apply it— President Quincy has done much, and has the best possible disposition to do more—but he wants countenance and support from abroad and he has the fear of man too much before his eyes.— I called also at the House of B. F. Hallett, and then at the Office of the Daily Advocate, where I found him— Had a conversation of two hours with him upon politics— He promised to republish the Article in the Bangor Courier of the 13th. upon Burges— He promised also to come out next Sunday Evening to see me, with Abel Cushing of Dorchester— I dined with Dr George Parkman—Edward Everett, Dr Shattuck, his wife and Sun Dr Wainwright, Dr Francis Parkman, Judge P. O. Thacher, a Mr Leverett and some others, were there— I talked too much— Dr Parkman walked home with me, and told me that he proposed to go with his family to Europe next March— Mr De Wint and his daughter Caroline, and a Mr Barnard spent the Evening with us at my Son Charles’s— Mr De Wint proposes to go to-morrow— Caroline is to stay some time with Harriet Welsh, at Mrs S. A. Otis’s.
22. IV:15. Thursday.— Return from Boston to Quincy.

After Breakfast, I called at Dr Bigelow’s house to consult him again upon the state of my health, and particularly upon my still disabled and inflamed hand but he was not at home. I then called upon Alexander H. Everett whom I found, and with whom I had about two hours of conversation— He said he would come out on Saturday afternoon to see me with Dr Julius who is here, and whom I met at the Exhibition at Cambridge on Tuesday— At noon I returned to Charles’s
house, and he took me out before dinner to Quincy. My wife had sent the Carriage in with Mrs Wilson and the little John Quincy for me— Charles’s wife with her daughter Louisa C. came out in the Carriage, and brought back John Quincy— They dined with us, and returned to Boston this Evening, leaving both the children here— Immediately after dinner, Mr Whitcomb and Mr Clap, a Clerk and Inspector of the Customs at Boston, came to request my aid to obtain an increase of their compensations in the Law to be enacted for regulating the Salaries of the Revenue Officers— They were here upwards of an hour, explaining their objects and their grievances, and they promised to draw up written statements, for me to take with me to Washington— I received on my return home several Letters—one signed Cephas Smith, full of bitter reproaches for my ingratitude to him, whom I never saw or heard of before; because he always was in my favour, and because I have disappointed him— A cover from Providence, with slips of all the abusive and malignant newspaper paragraphs, occasioned by my Letter to Pearce, from every part of the Union—a Letter from President Quincy, with the Report of the Royall Professor of Law S. Greenleaf, for the visitors— A Letter from Josiah Quincy junr.—with the two Deeds indentures of lease from the Supervisors of the Adams Temple and School-fund to Betsey Thayer— And a Letter of genealogical enquiries from Edward H. Adams, at Middleton Hall, near Carmarthen in South Wales— In the Evening I went to Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s, and then to his brother Daniel Greenleaf’s, where he was, to fix a time for the execution of the Deed to Mrs Thayer. We agreed it should be done on Saturday the 31st. of this month, if the attendance of President Quincy from Cambridge, and of Mr Edward Miller from Boston can be obtained— On my return home, I found Mr G. W. Beale and his daughter Ann here— This has been a day of much occupation, busied with many various calls of my attention, none of which however could extinguish the deep emotion of the remembrance, that it was the anniversary of the departure of my dear and ever lamented son John— A calamity, which with the agonies he had endured for two or three years before, and which broke his heart, bows me with sorrow to the grave.
23. IV:15. Friday

Walk with E. P. Greenleaf, round by the Neponset Bridge road, and Gulliver’s Brook. The day was much occupied with William Spear in making arrangements for the sale of the Oak timber on the Mount Wollaston farm, and with Alpheus Spear about the renewal of his lease— William Spear had received offers from Mr Josselyn, and Captain Souther for the timber— I authorised him to offer it to Josselyn for 750 dollars; but Josselyn rejected the proposal immediately— Captain Souther offered him 8 dollars and 16 2/3 cents a ton delivered at the yard. 100 dollars to be paid down, and the remainder within six months— I authorized him to accept this offer, and gave him a receipt signed by me, and an engagement to be signed by Mr Souther— Alpheus Spear was here with Josiah Adams junr. and had a plan for building a new house on the farm at Mount Wollaston, and for turning the old house into a barn. This with all the other repairs and charges that he wants will be burdensome, but he had no estimates made— He is to come with them to-morrow morning— Elizabeth C. Adams came to spend some days with my wife and Mary— I was in my Garden, Nursery and Seminary—had a number of trees transplanted—and set beyond the road South of my house. Emptied Pots N. 1. and 2 of their seedling maples, and planted in them brown Bury Pear Cores and Greenleaf large Appleseeds.
24. IV:15. Saturday

Josselyn came yesterday after I had authorised W. Spear, to close with Captain Souther, and complained that another offer had not been made to him— But he flatly refused that which was made, and I told him I did not know that he expected another offer— He was not a little nettled— This morning was showery; and prevented Mr. E. P. Greenleaf’s walk with me before Sunrise— The first interruption by the weather since we commenced our morning
walks on the 3d. day of September— Alpheus Spear came this Morning and agreed to renew his lease for five years from the 1st. of next April, with the understanding that I am to expend 2000 dollars in building a new farm house, and in making other alterations and repairs—his rent to be 800 dollars a year, and he to pay all the taxes— I read to him at his request the former lease and promised to draw up a new one for him to examine before executing it— He said he was drawn as a juryman, to go to the Supreme Court at Dedham, and expected to be engaged there the whole week— But he wished to have the affair of the lease settled before my departure for Washington— My Son Charles came out from Boston, dined with us and returned in the Evening— His account of the Resolutions passed by Anti-masonic members of the Legislature of Vermont, was somewhat discouraging— The Resolutions were reported by Slade, who smarting with his dismission from Office by Van-Buren, substitutes his resentments for principles and is leading the Anti-masonic party their away—into controvertible ground— But the Democratic party in Boston, have proposed to the Anti-masons to place Charles’s name on the list to be jointly supported for the State Senate at the approaching elections— He has determined however to decline this honour. I was confined the whole of this day to the house, and with great difficulty got through an answer to a Letter from George Bancroft— I am threatened with the loss of my right hand, for every purpose of writing—is it a visitation from Heaven, warning me to close all my accounts with this world? I fear it is— Yet let me not despair before my time— Josiah Adams junr was here this morning with Alpheus Spear, and the plan for building the farmhouse and making the repairs at Mount-Wollaston— He was here again in the Evening, and is to undertake the job, jointly with George Veazie—who would have preferred to undertake it alone— Adams spent nearly two hours with me, talking Anti-masonry and Politics— He says the Quincy Masonic Rural Lodge is broken up and dissolved. He told me also that there was this Evening a whig Webster Caucus at the Town-Hall—
25. IV. Sunday.— Anniversary of my father’s Marriage 1764.

Heard Mr Kendall of Medfield, this Morning from John 11.23 “Jesus saith unto her, thy brother shall rise again 24. Martha saith unto him, I know that he shall rise again in the resurrection at the last day 25. Jesus said unto her, I am the resurrection and the life: he that believeth in me, though he were dead, yet shall he live: 26. And whosoever liveth, and believeth in me, shall never die; Believest thou this?” After dinner—the text was from Ephesians 4.14. “That we henceforth be no more children tossed to and fro, and carried about by every wind of doctrine, by the sleight of men, and cunning craftiness, whereby they lie in wait to deceive.” Mr Kendall is a young man, Son of Dr Kendall of Plymouth— His Discourses were sensible and well-written; but inanimately delivered— He seemed to need the performance upon himself of a miracle; like that which formed the subject whence his text was drawn— To be raised from the dead— He noticed the difference between a restoration from death to life, as in the case of Lazarus; and the resurrection from the dead, at the judgment day— And gave it as his opinion, that the final resurrection was not with the same body which we have upon Earth.— I read the first Sermon of the 8th. volume of Saurin, upon the manner of praising God— Not one of the most satisfactory to me— I read also some pages of the Dissertation H. upon the Congress of Nation, the most verbose upon the evils of War of any that I have yet read— And I finished reading the second Volume of the Letters from Horace Walpole to Sir Horace Mann— They are very amusing— I was struck with one of them in which he mentions the publication of Bolingbroke’s three Treatises on the Spirit of Patriotism—the Patriot King, and on the State of Parties— In the last he denies that there was any design in the Ministry at the close of Queen Ann’s reign to restore the Stuarts— Exactly like the denial that the Hartford Convention was part of a project for a separation of these States and a Northern Confederacy— Walpole’s remark upon the impudent assertion of Bolingbroke, reminded me of H. G. Otis’s assertions equally bold, to whitewash the Hartford Convention.—
26. IV. Monday

Frosty morning— Walk with E. P. Greenleaf to the beach of the Mount Wollaston farm. I went to look for Acorns, but my fingers were so benumbed with cold that I could gather very few— I answered a Letter from a Committee of the Erodelphian Association of the Miami University, in the State of Ohio inviting me to deliver their Anniversary Address next September— I decline— I finished this morning the reading of Charles Thomson’s Translation of the Bible— The version of the Septuagint Old Testament is valuable as a curiosity and particularly as it is probable the Septuagint was the Bible in use by the Apostles, and perhaps by Jesus Christ himself— But in all other respects, as English composition the English Bible of James the first’s Translations, is incomparably superior to that of Mr Thomson— Mary, with Elizabeth C. Adams went to Boston this Morning and returned this Evening with Caroline De Wint— I planted in my garden row 13. of Garden button pear cores—Greenleaf Apple-seeds Shagbark walnuts, Acorns, Thornberries, Ash and Tulip-tree seeds— The state of my mind is deeply agitated, and I know not what to do, by reason of darkness— Would that a ray of light might flash upon my eyes to discern, how I may best discharge my duties to my country and to mankind—
27. IV. Tuesday.

Walk with Mr E. P. Greenleaf to the Penn’s hill grove in search of acorns, but it is now too late—they are almost all gone— I have set out two of my seedling Maples from the Pots, in the rings in front of my chamber windows, a mode of sowing seedlings which I began in October 1833, and which I am encouraged to continue— In one of those rings in line from the Southeast corner of the house to the road, with a Pot-seedling maple I this day sowed Nantucket Apple seeds, a Button Garden core, and seeds of another—Tulip-seeds and a shag-bark walnut— Charles and his wife came out and dined with us, and immediately after dinner returned to Boston, taking their daughter Louisa Catherine with them— Elizabeth C. Adams returned home to her Mother’s and took with her Caroline de Wint— Mr Beale, and his
daughter Ann, and Mr E. P. Greenleaf, and his Sister Mary Ann were here this Evening— I answered a Letter from R. W. Middleton, publisher of the Star and Republican Banner at Gettysburg Pennsylvania—and began one to D. J. Pearce— Read some pages of the Dissertation H. on the Congress of Nations and a few Letters in the 3d. Volume of Walpole to Mann— I began to read also the Prolegomena to Hewlett’s Commentary on the Bible
28. IV. Wednesday

Morning walk with E. P. Greenleaf to what I have called the Druid pasture; but scarcely any of the fallen Acorns are left— It is too late— Mr Thomas Greenleaf called on me,—about the execution of the Deed to Mrs Thayer— He has notified President Quincy and Mr Edward Miller, and the Selectmen to attend at his house at 3. O’Clock Saturday afternoon for that purpose. I am obliged to go into Boston that day, and to be there precisely at that time— I must therefore execute the deed separately— My Son Charles came out from Boston and dined with us— Then went to Mrs T. B. Adams’s and took Caroline de Wint with him to Boston— She is to depart to-morrow, upon her return home. Alexander H. Everett came out and took tea with us— I then walked with him to the Town-Hall, where he delivered a historical lecture on the French Revolution to the Quincy Lyceum— The Hall was full, with a respectable auditory of men women and boys. I asked Mr Everett to come home with me, but he had an engagement— His Lecture took about an hour in the delivery, and was very well written— It was a rapid review of the French Revolution, of course somewhat superficial, and with some super-simplifications to produce effect; but animated with good moral and political principles— My day was much wasted as usual— I wrote an answer to D. J. Pearce’s last Letter— Charles brought me a Boston Centinel, containing Mr Daniel Webster’s Speech on receiving the present of the Silver vase at the Odeon—on the 12th. instt— It is an aukward attempt to justify his political course for the last year, most especially upon the patronage-bill— His system now is to increase the power of Congress and to diminish the power of the Executive.
29. IV. Thursday.

My walk with Mr Greenleaf this Morning was round the Neponset Square, returning by Gulliver’s Brook.— Mary went to Boston to spend a week or ten days with Charles’s wife, and Louisa C. Smith came to pass some days with us. Dr Waterhouse came to dine with us and returned home this Evening. He communicated to me in confidence some of his domestic troubles; and, asked my advice— I advised him to mild and conciliatory measures, and he said he would act accordingly— He shewed me a copy of the Deed of Trust, by which William Sawyer is made the Trustee of all the property which came to him by his present wife, and he told me of some incidents of the household in which there were different views entertained by the two heads of the family— I recommended above all things Peace— The Doctor was born the 5th. of March 1754—and is of course in the 82d. year of his age— His bodily health is good; but the faculties of his mind are much impaired— He gave me one of Captain Jesse D. Elliot’s pamphlets in vindication of himself— William Spear called and paid me 100. dollars on account of Captain Souther’s purchase of timber trees standing on Mount Wollaston— Mr Josselyn is much discontented— I spoke to Mr Spear about the leasing to one person the farm at the foot of Penn’s Hill which is yet to be done Barnard Sargent came about the money for his Deed. Mr Frye has received it from Governor Cass, and deposited it to my credit in the U.S. Branch Bank Washington— I paid the fifty dollars to Mr Sargent and took his receipt— I planted a row of Apple and Pearseeds with Acorns Shagbark walnuts, Tulip-tree and Ash-seeds in the cleared hazel-bush patch; and sowed three rows of Garden button-wood pear seeds in Garden box N. 3— The Garden is now so cheerless and my seeds are in such quantities, that I keep no good record of the seeds sown, and whatever of them come up, will be as usual in confusion— I read 10 Morning pages of Hewlett’s prolegomena to his Bible commentary— A few evening Letters of Walpole, and H. on the Congress of Nations.
30. IV. Friday.

Our morning walk was round back of the old Mill-pond, and through the lot given by my father to the town; by the Stone quarries on Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s land, and a path coming out at the corner beyond his house— I answered a Letter from Thomas C. Hambly Editor of a Newspaper at York, Pennsylvania— Perhaps indiscreetly.— I received also a Letter from L. D. Dewey, concerning the Dissertations on the Congress of Nations; at the close of which he expresses his great satisfaction with my Letter to D. J. Pearce— The operation of that Letter upon the public mind has been remarkable— Pearce read it to Governor Francis and two or three others of his friends— The whigs heard of it, and it threw them into convulsions— They denied its existence, and extorted its publication— Then came the fury of the storm upon me— Almost all the newspapers of all the parties, not excepting some of the Anti-masonic, fell foul not so much of the Letter, as of the writer, and there is scarcely a reproach in the compass of the language, but they have heaped upon me— What is then my standing before the Nation; and how long will it be beforeHostile Millions press me to the ground—to be driven from the public service at the closing stage of Life, by a combination of all parties against me, is the prospect now before me, and it is a fortune corresponding to the general analogy of human affairs— My Letter to Pearce contained an admonition to the Statesmen of this Country, which might improve their morals— This is precisely the part which has passed unnoticed— I sowed a row promiscuous of Apple and Pear seeds, shagbark Acorns and wild Cherries in the cleared hazel-bush patch in the Garden; and had the Pots 3. 5 and 6. emptied of their Maple seedlings—transplanted to the interval rows in the same Hazel-bush Patch—Seedling Apple-stocks have been transplanted from the Nursery to the Orchard Eastward of it.
31. IV. Saturday.— Boston— Medford— Quincy

I sent to Mr Thomas Greenleaf the Indentures, between the Supervisors of the Adams Temple and School Fund, with the Selectmen of the Town of Quincy, and the widow Betsey Thayer— A Lease for one hundred years of a house lot, about half an Acre, on the Eight Acre lot given by my father to the Town.— This day had been fixed for the execution of it at my request; but my Son Charles having fixed also on this day for the baptism of his second Son, I was obliged to go to Boston to be present at that ceremony—and must execute the Deed, for my part some other day— I went into Boston, with my wife; and we took with us Charles’s eldest boy John Quincy, who has hitherto remained with us— I called at Charles’s Office, where I found William Spear and at Samuel Colman’s shop, and settled with him an Account for 14 parts, from 13 to 26. of the National Gallery of Portraits— At Noon Charles’s child was baptized, at his house, by Mr Frothingham, and named Charles Francis, after his father— Mr Peter C. Brooks, Mr Edward Brooks, Mrs P. C Brooks junr. and Mrs. Everett were present— After the ceremony I went with Charles to Medford and dined with Mr P. C Brooks— Edward Brooks, and Mr and Mrs. Edward Everett were there— Mrs. Frothingham is keeping Mr Brooks’s House— Immediately after dinner I returned with Charles to Boston—and then came with my wife home to Quincy— Mrs Kirk went and returned with us. We reached home about half past seven in the Evening— This day is the centurial anniversary of my fathers birth— On the 19th. of October 1735. Old Style, he was born— This is the 19th. of October 1835 Old Style— He was born of Parents in humble life, and has left an illustrious name, for his descendants to sustain by virtues like his own— May it please the disposer of all Events that his great-grandson this day devoted to the service of God and man, may enjoy as long, as useful and prosperous a life

Day— I rise between four and five O’Clock— Walk from five to eight miles before breakfast with E. Price Greenleaf— After breakfast, hear my Grand-child Mary Louisa read—sometimes twice— Dine between 2 and 3. P.M. visit my Garden, read or write till dark, and in the evening read a few of Horace Walpole’s Letters to Mann— But my hand is lame, and my eyes are almost blind.
